fields.description:
In some cases, CloudFormation provides JSON responses. For errors, boto handles this properly when it fails to parse XML and extracts the proper information from the JSON. Eucalyptus wraps the proper response in a "CloudFormationErrorResponse" object, so the expected values are found 1 level deeper in the JSON. This messes up boto's attempts to extract standard response values (request_id, message, error_code).
https://github.com/boto/boto/blob/develop/boto/exception.py#L119-L127

The response from AWS lacks this wrapper:
u'{"Error":{"Code":"ValidationError","Message":"Template file referenced by https://cf-template-429942273585-us-west-1.s3.amazonaws.com/cfn-as-launchconfig-paravirt-instanceprofile.json?Signature=W9mgzWRlMAqZe1n0%2BM9gmmFLIF8%3D&Expires=1425670813&AWSAccessKeyId=ASIAIPHT3XGEH2GINPHQ&x-amz-security-token=AQoDYXdzEN3//////////wEa8AHGhON5Y9xtxXv79F9WCUnNWHAo4We9n4GIQGsrOJ9HmW/Niksj/m7mliigTqw0GTQS48R/v8bVuRo5B8BYWMVBqPvJ%2BIEKozO%2B48grz17fjy8gflb%2BGbwv/N4Fb0KORiX51GCm0xosId5dMBcrbJH5pn2fvwItEz2CvEnYTG3WN/abDuJD6qJeqvRGqIgG%2BFtjP/voQDWeIw5%2BFSwhFXyd29tu3NX12E8oy1DsO/Nox6UO92%2Ba8T0%2B0zcwn3JPZsLlDHutpSgNEjV85xolGEAQQt1FYihnTn/lkTL2UXcISgNWUKbsmZ%2BJQZqQR0ocY04gm4DopwU%3D does not exist.","Type":"Sender"},"RequestId":"edbe8968-c437-11e4-bac0-25d29c2758a9"}'

comments.body: we don't get any server error messages, so UX suffers till this is fixed.
[~mmunn1], that should. If you had a machine running your branch, I could test the console against it to be 100% sure. I'd need a user login w/ password to test with.
Error is a single dictionary in AWS's response. In Euca, it's an array of dictionaries. Let's remove the array wrapper.

[~dkavanagh] I have changed the code  to return xml instead of json in the case of a CloudFormationErrorResponse in my dev branch, can you see if this works for you. Same box as before for testing. I will need to look into the full implications of this approach but lets see if it works for you first.

Nice, [~mmunn1], ship it!

To be more clear, I've created an error condition on stack create in the console and got a proper error message back in my alert.

Code Review Request : EUCA-10625 CloudFormation JSON incorrectly wraps response

branch : dev-mmunn1-EUCA-10625

diff :  git show --color 83f6a72e3144539870b4d8d239caea5116f053ee

Summary: CloudFormationErrorResponse returned json using boto that was not parsed poperly in console 

Solution: return xml in the case of CloudFormationErrorResponse.

Unit test : described in comments

[~mmunn1] I'd rather send JSON back when we can, especially since AWS does so.  Boto will parse XML on error responses, just in case the wrong URL is entered and no json is sent back at all.  I think you were on the right track in the approach when you had your JSON in an earlier comment, but the "Error" field appears to be an array there.  The nice thing about XML is that you can do <Error>...</Error> ... <Error>...</Error> with one or more errors and if you have a single one, it will appear not to be an array.  

What I would do is go back to JSON, and originally what I would have said is to but change the error field in CloudFormationErrorResponse from an array to a single element, and change CloudFormationMessages.groovy, cloudformation-binding.xml, and CloudFormationErrorResponse accordingly.  I don't think that part should be done, however, as that will affect all error responses, and non-boto responses seem to work just fine for now.

What I would do is in the JSON response, look for the "Error": [] response, and find the first element in that array, and change it to "Error" : {first item in list}.  It's kind of a hack, but it appears that you have already done something to the original value.  One thing you could do is create a new class CloudFormationJsonErrorResponse, and have it have the same fields as the original CloudFormationErrorResponse just change the error to a single element, populate it from the other object, and set the error field to the first element in the array,  This will lessen the need to directly manipulate the JSON.

The reasons not to do what is currently under review is
1) Not all errors are necessarily 400 response codes.
2) AWS doesn't return XML in this instance.  (I don't think)

[~mmunn1] The only issue I can see is if any part of these items has json code in it (like quotes or something) it might not escape things properly.  You might want to use ObjectMapper.writeValueAsString() with your strings.  It is probably ok as is though.  I would leave request-id as request id, that's what AWS appears to do here.
[~ethomas] I think that by getting the individual fields values from the CloudFormationErrorResponse we avoid that issue.
@mmunn1, I was talking about if the field values themselves contain quotes.  I think that is highly unlikely though.
[~dkavanagh] If the latest version of this fix works for you I will go ahead and check it in. ( same Box for testing)
[~mmunn1], I have some pending changes in this area as part of EUCA-10892 so please hold off on this until that makes it into QA (hopefully today)
[~sjones] I will wait for EUCA-10892 to be integrated to evaluate.
[~dkavanagh] Are you still seeing this issue after Steve's changes?
I have not. Jenny had a weird case where she saw the blank red box, but was unable to reproduce.
[~dkavanagh] can I close this as resolved?
